articles.headline: For Flip Video Camera, Four Years From Hot Start-Up to Obsolete
articles.snippet: The camera had been a great hardware start-up success, but it lost traction as the smartphone came on the scene.
articles.abstract: The camera had been a great hardware start-up success, but it lost traction as the smartphone came on the scene.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was one of the great tech start-up success stories of the last decade.
articles.byline: By Sam Grobart and Evelyn M. Rusli

articles.headline: Hospital Is Drawn Into Bahrain Strife
articles.snippet: Human rights groups say arrests of medical workers are meant to instill terror in doctors, so they will not care for wounded protesters.
articles.abstract: Human rights groups say arrests of medical workers are meant to instill terror in doctors, so they will not care for wounded protesters.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANAMA, Bahrain — A handful of soldiers, their faces covered by black masks to hide their identities, guard the front gate of Salmaniya Medical Complex. Inside, clinics are virtually empty of patients, many of whom, doctors say, have been hauled away for detention after participating in protests.

articles.headline: Countering the Siege
articles.snippet: Gerald McEntee, 76, who has led the largest public employee union for 30 years, is mobilizing as his members’ rights and benefits are under assault.
articles.abstract: Gerald McEntee, 76, who has led the largest public employee union for 30 years, is mobilizing as his members’ rights and benefits are under assault.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Perhaps more than any other American, Gerald W. McEntee has surfed the rising tide of public sector unions to success and power. As leader of the largest union of state and local government workers for three decades, he has amassed enormous political influence and a huge campaign war chest that he has not hesitated to use to advance his union’s interests.

articles.headline: High Prices Sow Seeds of Erosion
articles.snippet: The farmland scourge of soil erosion, once on the decline, is again a threat, scientists and environmentalists say.
articles.abstract: The farmland scourge of soil erosion, once on the decline, is again a threat, scientists and environmentalists say.
articles.lead_paragraph: When prices for corn and soybeans surged last fall, Bill Hammitt, a farmer in the fertile hill country of western Iowa, began to see the bulldozers come out, clearing steep hillsides of trees and pastureland to make way for more acres of the state’s staple crops. Now, as spring planting begins, with the chance of drenching rains, Mr. Hammitt worries that such steep ground is at high risk for soil erosion — a farmland scourge that feels as distant to most Americans as tales of the Dust Bowl and Woody Guthrie ballads.

articles.headline: Lobbyists Won Key Concessions in Budget Deal
articles.snippet: In the end, a handful of relatively small-bore line items affecting particular industries attracted some of the most aggressive lobbying behind the scenes in the budget battle.
articles.abstract: In the end, a handful of relatively small-bore line items affecting particular industries attracted some of the most aggressive lobbying behind the scenes in the budget battle.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At a quarter till midnight last Friday, with a deal to avert a government shutdown barely an hour old, Senator Harry Reid phoned a fellow Democratic senator, Ron Wyden, at home and startled him with some bad news. “You lost free-choice vouchers,” Mr. Wyden recalls Mr. Reid telling him.

articles.headline: Pace of Attacks in Libya Conflict Is Dividing NATO
articles.snippet: France and Britain openly called on the alliance and its partners to intensify airstrikes, prompting an unusual public retort from NATO’s command.
articles.abstract: France and Britain openly called on the alliance and its partners to intensify airstrikes, prompting an unusual public retort from NATO’s command.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With the United States limiting itself to a supporting role in the conflict in Libya, fissures opened among NATO allies on Tuesday over the scope and intensity of attacks against the forces of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, officials here and in Europe said.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Do-Nothing Congress as a Cure
articles.snippet: The expiration of the Bush tax cuts would mean a return to the Clinton tax rates and a good start to a smaller deficit.
articles.abstract: The expiration of the Bush tax cuts would mean a return to the Clinton tax rates and a good start to a smaller deficit.

articles.headline: As the Mountaintops Fall, a Coal Town Vanishes
articles.snippet: A small town in West Virginia has essentially disappeared in the wake of the state’s largest surface-mining operation.
articles.abstract: A small town in West Virginia has essentially disappeared in the wake of the state’s largest surface-mining operation.
